awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: KMELIN: Knowledge Mining and Embedding Learning for Complex Dynamic Information Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Complex dynamic information networks (CDINs) consist of data objects that are highly correlated with a variety of dependency relationships, such as patient-physician interactions or patient-medication-insurance claims. Each data object as a CDIN node has rich contents, such as biometric information of a patient, disease symptoms, or hospital logistics. Data objects and their relationships also continuously evolve and change. Many health, social, physical, and biological systems share the CDIN essence that the multifaceted and dynamic nature of individual nodes imposes significant challenges for modeling a complex and evolving network as a whole. Although data relationships are becoming rich and comprehensive than ever, existing systems are mostly relational-database driven, and cannot integrate complex relationships of networked data for Big Data analytics.

This project aims to design a knowledge mining and embedding learning platform for CDINs that will (1) extract and represent complex structure and rich-content information in the health domain as a CDIN; (2) perform knowledge mining, including clustering and classification, on CDIN networks; (3) enable feature embedding learning with CDINs, so the users can interact with CDINs for content access, and (4) provide a prototype system for hospital re-admission decision support. The spectrum of the methods from the project will not only enrich algorithms and solutions for mining complex structure and rich content networks, as opposed to static networks, but also shift existing health information systems from traditional databases towards becoming network centered systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The project aims to study knowledge mining and embedding learning algorithms for complex dynamic information networks that extract and represent complex structure and rich-content information in the networks (with a focus on the health domain).

Research Outcomes: During the funding period, our research results have been published in 56 peer reviewed journals or conference proceedings. Many papers are published at top venues, such as International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence (IJCAI), IEEE International Conference on Data Mining (ICDM), IEEE Trans. on Neural Networks and Learning Systems, IEEE Trans. on Big Data, ACM Computing Survey etc. Several publications have received high citations, indicating our research impact to the community. For example, our paper on network representation learning published in 2020 (IEEE Trans. on Big Data) has received 800 citations.  Another paper on dropout and batch normalization in deep learning has received 500 citations since 2020.

Graduate Student Training: Under the NSF project support, five PhD students and one MS student successfully graduated and received their degrees during the funding period (three of the six students are female students). All six students’ dissertation/thesis research are centered around the knowledge mining and feature embedding learning algorithms.

Data and Knowledge Sharing: As part of our research contribution, we continuously publish data, especially the ones related to health and biomedical network data, for public usage and sharing. During the funding period, we published six datasets for public sharing: (1) Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) gene-disease networks: A heterogeneous gene-disease COPD network, which can be used to valid heterogeneous network classification; (2) Infectious disease clinical trial network: A sponsor-research relationships network related to infectious disease clinical trials collected from 4,228 clinical trial reports; (3) Clinical trial dataset. This dataset is created from 311,260 clinical trials downloaded from clinicaltrials.gov. After data processing, we created a testbed with 68,999 trials, where 88.54% trials (61,095) were completed and 11.46% trials (7,094) were terminated; (4) COVID-19 clinical trial datasets: This dataset is created from 772 COVID-19 clinical trials; (5) COVID-19 test and symptom dataset includes 2,467 rows (donors) and 37 features (such as age group, gender, symptoms). This dataset is not published for public access but can be requested and is subject to the industry partner’s approval; and (6) Manatee counting dataset includes 786 manually labelled images, each verified by multiple students, as well as the region of the manatees for pattern learning.

Workforce Training and Professional Development: The project research activities, data, and algorithms have been disseminated in the graduate courses, such as CAP 6619: Deep Learning, CAP 6635: Artificial Intelligence, CAP 6315: Social Networks and Big Data Analytics, CAP 5615: Introduction to Neural Networks, etc. During the funding period, the PI has used the project research materials to help train 1,349 graduate students in the classes he taught. The research materials have also been used to help train students from NSF Cyber-training program and high school students from Florida Science Olympiad.

Public Dissemination and News Medica Coverage: Several research outcomes from the project have been disseminated or reported by news media worldwide. For example, our research on using deep neural networks to help save endangered species has been reported in over 20 news, TV interview, and broadcast.

 


Last Modified: 10/13/2024
Modified by: Xingquan Zhu

Research Outcomes: During the funding period, our research results have been published in 56 peer reviewed journals or conference proceedings. Many papers are published at top venues, such as International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence (IJCAI), IEEE International Conference on Data Mining (ICDM), IEEE Trans. on Neural Networks and Learning Systems, IEEE Trans. on Big Data, ACM Computing Survey etc. Several publications have received high citations, indicating our research impact to the community. Workforce Training and Professional Development: The project research activities, data, and algorithms have been disseminated in the graduate courses, such as CAP 6619: Deep Learning, CAP 6635: Artificial Intelligence, CAP 6315: Social Networks and Big Data Analytics, CAP 5615: Introduction to Neural Networks, etc. During the funding period, the PI has used the project research materials to help train 1,349 graduate students in the classes he taught.
